topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Ken Norton’s Google product leadership background and current work as an executive coach, plus a preview of topics they’ll cover in the episode.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Amplitude and Lenny’s Job Board.

topics.title: Donut metaphor and remote equivalent
topics.summary: They discuss Ken’s famous “bring donuts” PM metaphor as servant leadership, and brainstorm remote-friendly equivalents (including DoorDash donut codes).

topics.title: What executive coaching is and why Ken coaches
topics.summary: Ken defines coaching as a client-led partnership focused on the whole person (not just product), emphasizing listening and curiosity; he shares how his own coach and his GV experience shifted him away from advice-giving toward coaching.

topics.title: Who seeks coaching and when
topics.summary: Ken describes typical clients (senior product leaders and execs) and common triggers like role transitions, career crossroads, and the realization that internal work is needed to level up.

topics.title: Internal operating system vs skills (driving analogy)
topics.summary: Using teaching his son to drive, Ken explains how leadership growth often requires a shift in meaning-making and self-complexity—not just learning tactics—because your role in a complex system changes.

topics.title: Leadership unlock: creative versus reactive mindset
topics.summary: Ken introduces the core leadership distinction (creative/above-the-line vs reactive/below-the-line), why it’s more effective, and why most leaders still operate reactively due to fear-based default patterns.

topics.title: Reactive postures: approval, rightness, control
topics.summary: They unpack how reactive leadership shows up as fear/anxiety and three common postures: seeking approval, needing to be right, and needing control; Ken shares how these can be adaptive early but costly later.

topics.title: Shifting from people-pleasing to purpose-led leadership
topics.summary: Ken explains why the shift isn’t ‘stop caring’ but reframing values into a creative mode—e.g., trading immediate likability for long-term admiration—plus how coaching and feedback tools help rewire beliefs.

topics.title: Authentic leadership and career navigation
topics.summary: Lenny shares a coaching insight about leveraging strengths; Ken connects this to finding roles/environments that fit your authentic leadership style and moving from external validation to internal purpose.

topics.title: Coaching vs mentoring and when coaching fits
topics.summary: They distinguish coaching (finding your way) from mentorship (concrete advice), and Ken explains coaching is most useful once you’ve mastered basics and need deeper internal transformation.

topics.title: Finding coaching without a coach: self-work and resources
topics.summary: Ken argues coaching can be more accessible than people think and doesn’t require domain experience; he suggests self-coaching, values work, coach-like mentors/managers, and recommends books/resources (Dare to Lead, 15 Commitments, Mastering Leadership, Immunity to Change).

topics.title: Common PM blind spot: people over product
topics.summary: Ken says senior product leadership challenges are mostly people problems (influence, collaboration, difficult personalities, vision); he urges PMs to treat ‘soft skills’ as core craft and train them like any other skill.

topics.title: Transition to imposter syndrome discussion (cut off)
topics.summary: Lenny tees up imposter syndrome as a recurring coaching theme and begins asking what Ken advises, but the transcript ends mid-question.
